ygData.subject: Re: long simulations
ygData.msgSnippet: The number of inputs and outputs can raise the potential level of behavioral complexity to some extent, but it doesn t really determine it.  Consider that if

The number of inputs and outputs can raise the potential level of 
behavioral complexity to some extent, but it doesn't really 
determine it.  Consider that if everyone in the world suddenly 
became deaf, we would not be any less intelligent, or any less 
strategically sophisticated.  Similarly, no one would suggest that 
someone who can't move is somehow less sophisticated than anyone 
else, although they may have fewer "outputs".   So it really isn't 
about how many inputs or outputs something has, but rather it is 
more about the richness of the domain.  (Of course, at the extreme 
low end, e.g. just one output, it can have a direct limiting effect)

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "t_bommel" <t_bommel@y...> wrote:
> hey,
> 
> that make sense. does the level of strategy have to do with the 
> number of inputs and outputs (ie does more inputs and outputs 
imply 
> greater strategy)? also, how do you know when they agents have 
maxed 
> out the strategy of the environment?
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...> 
wrote:
> > Timmy,
> > 
> > A big problem with setting up an experiment like that is that 
the 
> > domain has to be sufficiently complex to support extremely 
complex 
> > strategies that continue to improve for millions of 
generations.  
> In 
> > Robot Duel, for example, there is only so good you can get, and 
> > after that the domain can't support anything more interesting 
> > because the game has been mastered as much as possible.  
> > 
> > We know games like Go support a very wide range of complexity, 
but 
> > in a game like that the problem is that stagnation is likely to 
set 
> > in as search finds certain strategic plateaus that are hard to 
get 
> > out of.
> > 
> > Nevertheless, it is possible that stagnation we observe in 1,000 
> > generation runs isn't actually stagnation when viewed from the 
> > vantage point of millions of generations, but who knows?
> > 
> > Here is a well-recognized and interesting challenge:  Design a 
> > domain, maybe a robot domain like robot duel, where there is 
room 
> > for virtually *unlimited* ever-increasing complexity.  It turns 
out 
> > this is very hard to do, and most domains turn out to have a 
limit 
> > to how much intelligence can help after a certain point.  Such 
> > domains are called "open-ended," and designing them to be truly 
> open-
> > ended is perhaps as hard as AI itself.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "t_bommel" <t_bommel@y...> wrote:
> > > hey,
> > > 
> > > has anyone created a simulation of considerable complexity 
like 
> > ken's 
> > > robot dual domain and let it run for very long period of time 
> like 
> > a 
> > > million generations to see what kind of strategies evolve? i 
was 
> > just 
> > > kinda curious to know how far competative co evolution could 
go. 
> > > anyway thanks
> > > 
> > > timmy
